newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai officials say Iraq rice purchases unlikely.
newsitem.headline: Thai officials say Iraq rice purchases unlikely.

text.p: Doubts over the future of the U.N. oil-for-food deal with Iraq after the U.S. missile attack on that country further reduce the chances that Iraq will buy Thai rice, industry and Commerce Ministry officials said on Wednesday.
Iraq had approached the Commerce Ministry earlier this year to buy 250,000 tonnes of Thai rice on credit terms and an unspecified amount of cash, one official said.
But in July, the government decided to turn down the request because the Thai Export-Import Bank would not approve the one-year credit sought by Iraq.
However, Iraq may turn to private Thai exporters because it was known to need 400,000 to 500,000 tonnes of rice, the official said.
Market sources said they had not heard of private deals with Iraq, but agreed that the collapse of the oil-for-food programme would make exporters even more reluctant to sell to Iraq.
The U.S. launched cruise missile against air defence targets in Iraq in retaliation for Baghdad's attacks on Kurdish groups in the country's north.
Thailand has not shipped sugar directly to Iraq for some years now, but traders said some sugar imported from Thailand by Jordan might have slipped into the country.
Jordan imported 30,000 tonnes of white sugar from Thailand between January and July this year, according to international surveyor Overseas Merchandise Inspection Co.
